description.narrative:
Denna insats berör förutom insats 51000177 också insatserna 51000184, 51000185, 51000186 och 51000187 i Sidas ekonomiadministrationssystem.
Sociala kontantbidrag är ett centralt fattigdomsminskande instrument i utvecklingsländer. I ett antal svenska samarbetsländer i Afrika söder om Sahara pågår redan initiativ på området och intresset bedöms öka i flera andra länder där svenskt utvecklingssamarbete pågår. Men mer information om vilka typer av interventioner som gett önskade effekter är nödvändigt. Därför föreslås nu Sverige via Sida finansiellt stödja ett projekt med UNICEFs forskningskontor, Office of Research, som syftar till att ta fram evidens från fallstudier i Afrika för beslutsfattare och myndighetspersoner i afrikanska länder söder om Sahara. Projektets kostnad uppgår till 10 MSEK för åren 2014-2017 och finansieras med medel från fem avräkningskonton, de för samarbetet i Kenya, Mocambique, Rwanda, Uganda och Tanzania.
Målen med projektet är att: 1) samla kunskap och forskningbaserad evidens kring sociala kontantbidrags effekter för utsatta, fattiga familjer och barn 2) påverka utformningen av sociala bidragprogram genom lättillgänglig och handlingsinriktad information 3) skapa grund för erfarenhets- och kunskapsutbyte över den afrikanska kontinenten om hur man bäst utformar sociala bidragssystem.

Multi-country research and learning initiative intended to further knowledge about impacts of social cash transfers in Africa. Led by UNICEF Office of Research in partnership with Save the Children-UK, FAO-Rome and the University of North Carolina. Aim: provide evidence on effectiveness of social cash transfers in achieving impacts for poor families and children. Funds reallocated fr UGA RWA TZA MOZ KEN

The Transfer Project is a multi-country research and learning initiative that is intended to further our knowledge about the impacts of social cash transfers in Africa.Objectives: 1) to provide evidence on the effectiveness of social cash transfer (SCT) programs in achieving impacts for poor families and children ; 2) to inform the development and design of social cash transfer policy and programs through ‘actionable’ and accessible research; 3) to promote learning and capacity building across the continent on the design, implementation and evaluation of social cash transfer programs.

sector.narrative: Social protection and welfare services policy, planning and administration

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Results have been achieved in all results areas, with some of the key achievements highlighted below. Several peer-reviwed articles and working papers have been published, and one major achievement is a culminating study that debunks myths around transfer which was finalised in 2017. Using data from eight Transfer Project impact evaluations in seven countries (Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe), the study combats perceptions about unconditional cash transfers as poverty reducation strategies in Africa, such as "cash transfers are wasted on alcohol and tobacco", "cash transfer to households young children will increase fertility" etc. Another key milestone includes the publication of the book compendium titled "From Evidence to Action: The Story of Cash Transfers and Impact Evaluation in Sub-Saharan Africa". With Sida funding, the Transfer Project has also provided support to six early career, African research fellows at Innocenti. In 2016, a research partnership agreement with African Economic Research Consortium (AERC) was finalised, and Innocenti-researchers led an impact evaluation workshop for 20 PhD students at AERC's bi-annual conference in Dakar using Transfer Project data. Another result to be highlighted is the Transfer Project bi-annual regional research workshop in 2017, held in Dakar, Senegel. The workshop gathered 120 participants, the majority representing African governments or implementing agencies from 24 different African countries and provided sharing of latest research and exchange of experience between policy makers and researchers in Africa. The Transfer project has continously provided technical assistance and oversight over impact evaluations, and in total 14 rounds of data collection were conducted in Ghana, Tanzania, Zambia, Malawi and Zimbabwe during the project period, exceeding the number of planned rounds initially proposed (3).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
